text: hi my name is Rebecca and in today's
lesson we're going to be talking about
paraphrasing now what is power phrasing
and why is it important paraphrasing is
expressing the same ideas that you have
heard or read in your own words in
different words why is it difficult to
do this because sometimes when we hear
something or read something that sounds
quite good we have a tendency to want to
copy that
however we can't because that's called
copying the proper word for that is
called plagiarism which is actually
looked upon quite seriously as an
offense in University and in academic
life in general and also in professional
life so it's really important for you to
learn to be able to express something
that you have heard or read about in
your own language so I'm going to show
you with in this video some strategies
to help you to do them let's look at
what they are okay so I have here six
different techniques you can use when
you want to paraphrase something or when
you want to express something in your
own words and I'm going to give you some
examples as we go along of each one the
first one is to use a synonym for the
word in the sentence so for example just
going to grab my examples here alright
so if your original sentence is the
hardest language to learn is Mandarin
the hardest language to learn is
Mandarin if I want to paraphrase that
sentence I could say the most difficult
language to learn is bedroom
so what I've done here is I substituted
most difficult for harvest this is one
way but it's still not a good power
phrase because it's too close to the
original sentence so I could now change
a couple of words if my original
sentence is the hardest language to
learn is Mandarin I could say the most
difficult language to master is Mandarin
now I've changed two parts I've changed
artists to most difficult and I've
changed learn to master this is better
but it still sounds a lot like the
original doesn't it
okay so here's another option we could
say Mandarin is one of the most
difficult languages to master now we
have a more successful power phrase
because we have changed not only words
using different synonyms we've also
changed the order of the words so we
have a more effective paraphrase and
that would be a good one
hi let's look now at a second method the
second method is to use an entity and
antonin as you know is a word that means
the opposite so this is a fairly easy
technique which you can fall back on
when you're really not sure what else to
do an example of this would be instead
of saying the man is tall you could say
the man is not short okay instead of
saying the school is far away you could
say the school is not near this is an
example of using antonyms it's a fairly
basic simple technique and you can use
it once in a while not all the time but
you can use it successfully alright the
third way is to use a phrasal verb so
let's look at an example of this she
discarded her used lipstick case in the
trash can she discarded or used lipstick
case in the trash can let's suppose that
we want to replace the word discarded
with a phrasal verb so what could you
use do you know what it means to
discourage something to discard
something means to throw it away that's
right so we could use here she threw
away her used lipstick case instead of
she discarded because if you keep using
the same words that were used in your
original passage whether it's a reading
passage or listening text then that
would not be considered paraphrasing
okay so what we're looking for is to
successfully substitute those words with
our own words and also to resist the
temptation to copy or use those words no
matter how wonderful they may be okay
let's look at another technique and this
is sometimes being able to use a general
verb so for example if you had a
sentence that said the factory
manufactures boxes right the factory
manufactures boxes you could substitute
it with a synonym like the factory
produces boxes or you could use a more
general verb the factory makes boxes
it's not as effective but at least
you're not using the same word all right
and lastly we could use phrases so for
phrases what we mean is
thing like this let's suppose that our
original sentence is many people in
Canada are bilingual okay
many people in Canada are bilingual so
let's suppose that you want to find a
substitute for the word bilingual what
could you say well what does bilingual
mean by is a prefix which means two and
lingual has to do with languages by
lingual means you speak two languages so
you can just use a phrase to the library
on that word or to explain that word so
you could say many people in Canada
speak two languages or many people in
Canada are binding these two sentences
are the same but at the same time you
haven't copied the exact words again
more successfully you would also be
changing the structure of the sentence
and not only individual words but these
are some techniques to do that now what
happens if you find a particularly
delightful sentence or word in your
reading passage and you really don't
want to power phrase it or you don't
know how to paraphrase it okay both of
these situations can occur so what do
you do then well in that case it is
possible to use a quotation which is
what I have here as your last option you
can put the quotation you can use an
entire sentence and put it in quotation
marks you could use certain expression
and put it in quotation marks when I'm
going like this it means quotation marks
okay because quotation marks and six of
two commas two apostrophes at the top
and two apostrophes at the end of it so
that's called a quotation so when people
go like this they mean quotation and if
you saw that episode of friends then
you'll know what I'm talking about where
Ross does something so
to that okay so these are some
techniques that you can use for power
phrasing which is a really important
skill in academic life in your TOEFL
exam and your IELTS exam or any other
exam or any other type of writing you
may need to do in your life all right
so I hope I've been able to help you
with that good luck with paraphrasing
bye for now
